Flutter requires installation and setup of cocoapods in order to deploy apps on iOS devices.

The setup of cocoapods is crashing on the new macOS hardware, see https://feedbackassistant.apple.com/feedback/8612629

Would be nice if fluter switched to a different package management solution.

Comment blurb from @chinmaygarde 

> CocoaPods is used to manage native dependencies on the hosts. It seems like one of the dependencies of CocoaPods has a native dependency that is crashing on this host. We need to track a fix for this with CocoaPods or switch to a different package management solution.

Autofill doesn't work on Android when a project has been created with an older, pre-v1.12 version of Flutter.

Autofill worked fine for us on iOS, but on Android the debug autofill provider would tell us that no autofill hints were found on the text field.

This is reproducible:

1. Downgrade to a pre-v1.12 version of Flutter - `flutter version v1.9.1+hotfix.6`
2. Create a project
3. Upgrade to latest stable, 1.20.2
4. Add a text field with autofill hints
5. Run on Android, and find that autofill doesn't work

I tried upgrading to the beta channel, and saw a warning linking to https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Upgrading-pre-1.12-Android-projects, on a hunch I followed the steps and autofill started working.

I guess the question is: is this a bug that needs fixing? Or should it just be documented, or have Flutter show a warning? Either way, it’s very confusing and I’m sure it’ll bite other developers with older projects.

CC @LongCatIsLooong (also: autofill is awesome, thank you!)

I want to implement custom keyboard shortcuts for desktop and web in our flutter web.  

For example: 
We are building a school organization app. 
If a user is on the homework page they should be able to create a new homework via `CTRL + N` instead of clicking an extended FAB.

**The problem is that it's even hard to find out if keyboard shortcuts are supported yet**.
Much less how to implement them if they are supported.

Google searches for flutter keyboard shortcuts are often referring to keyboard shortcuts for flutter IDEs.  
There is no (at least I couldn't directly find one) article about keyboard shortcuts.

What I could find:
- https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/31946 "Keyboard shortcuts and actions should be supported." (Closed)
Not much context, it seems like this is only for standard keyboard shortcuts like TAB, ENTER, CTRL-Z and meant as something which helps the Flutter to natively support these. Nothing for me as a developer for my own app to use (from what I understand).
- A Stackoverflow question with no answers: ["How to handle keyboard shortcuts"](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61960260/how-to-handle-keyboard-shortcuts)
- The [`Shortcuts`](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Shortcuts-class.html)/[`ShortcutManager`](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/ShortcutManager-class.html) Widgets with **sub-par documentation**.
There is no context on why these classes exist, what problems they solve and what problems they do not solve.
There are no examples.
I have no idea if these widgets help me or not with my problem.
- The [`keyboard_shortcuts`](https://pub.dev/packages/keyboard_shortcuts) package.
I haven't used it yet, it seems like something that could work. Nonetheless this is a package by a single person for a universal problem which in my opinion should be solved by Flutter.

So my points are that there should be Guidance if keyboard shortcuts are already supported by Flutter.  
If they aren't I would wish for a single ticket for keyboard shortcuts for web and desktop that is easily searchable and where the current state and the the next steps are documented.
If they are there should be documentation on how to implement them with examples.

According to the guide on flutter.dev about [create-a-build-archive](https://flutter.dev/docs/deployment/ios#create-a-build-archive), we need to run `flutter build ios` before we use Xcode to archive and get the IPA for AppStore/TestFlight.

But is it necessary to do such job? It seems that I use Xcode to archive without running the flutter build command, I also get the release-IPA correctly. So, what's the different if I run the command before archive?

For example, if I use `flutter build ios --bundle-sksl-path flutter_01.sksl.json` to build the app with **SkSL warm-up**, then use Xcode to archive afterward, is the IPA summiting to AppStore/TestFlight including the SkSL warm-up already? Or I should use the runner.app in folder `my_project\build\ios\iphoneos\` and compress it to IPA myself?

## Steps to Reproduce
This is the code from main.dart file which should be enough to reproduce the issue. 

<details>
 <summary>Minimal reproducible code sample</summary>

```dart
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(App());
}

class App extends StatelessWidget {
  final String title = 'Nested ReorderableListView Issue';
  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return MaterialApp(
      title: title,
      home: MyHomePage(title: title),
    );
  }
}

class MyHomePage extends StatelessWidget {
  final String title;
  final List outer = ['one', 'two', 'three'];
  final List inner = ['uno', 'dos', 'tres'];

  MyHomePage({this.title});

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Scaffold(
      appBar: AppBar(title: Text(title)),
      body: Center(
        child: Container(
          // main list containing nested reorderable lists
          child: ReorderableListView(
            // OuterListItem contains nested ReorderableListView
            children: outer.map<Widget>((oe) => OuterListItem(
              key: ValueKey(oe),
              children: inner.map((ie) => InnerListItem(
                key: ValueKey('$oe.$ie'),
                text: ie  
              )).toList(),
            )).toList(),
            onReorder: (cIndex, nIndex) {}
          ),
          
          height: 300,
          width: 400,
          padding: EdgeInsets.all(10),
          decoration: BoxDecoration(border: Border.all(width: 5)),
        )
      ),
    );
  }
}

class OuterListItem extends StatelessWidget {
  final Key key; 
  final List<Widget> children;

  const OuterListItem({this.key, this.children}) : super(key: key);

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Container(
      key: key,
      child: ReorderableListView(
        children: children,
        scrollDirection: Axis.horizontal,
        onReorder: (cIndex, nIndex) {}
      ),
      decoration: BoxDecoration(
        border: Border.all(
          color: Colors.pinkAccent,
          width: 3,
        ),
      ),
      margin: EdgeInsets.only(bottom: 10),
      height: 100,
    );
  }
}

class InnerListItem extends StatelessWidget {
  final Key key;
  final String text;

  const InnerListItem({this.key, this.text}): super(key: key);

  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return Card(
      key: key,
      child: Container(
        child: Center(
          child: Text(text),
        ),
        height: 100,
        width: 100,
      ),
      elevation: 2,
      color: Colors.yellow[300],
    );
  }
}
```
</details>

## Use case

Developers occasionally need to apply an ImageFilter to part of their Widget tree. We created a BackdropFilter widget to satisfy a common use of that technique, but there were other uses for which it was not as suited, such as blurring a widget in isolation. It is possible to use BackdropFilter to achieve those other results, but the construction is not obvious and there are a number of pitfalls that a developer can fall into.

More recently a new ImageFiltered widget was added which more directly serves the other needs to filter a part of an app with a more straightforward construction and an easier to manage behavior. But, developers continue to use BackdropFilter as it has been around longer and has more awareness built for it.

## Proposal

Document the existence of the two widgets in each other's doc comments and provide examples and guidance on when to use each.

#58154 added `tristate` for `CheckboxListTile` but did not update the logic for what actually happens when the user taps on the list tile to call `onChanged`.

the documentation reads:

>  /// When a tri-state checkbox ([tristate] is true) is tapped, its [onChanged]
>  /// callback will be applied to true if the current value is false, to null if
>  /// value is true, and to false if value is null (i.e. it cycles through false
>  /// => true => null => false when tapped).

But the implementation does not support this:

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/d1583fc39b8044d8e92fed63a01e0b523ce248b7/packages/flutter/lib/src/material/checkbox_list_tile.dart#L419

hence when trying to use it with tristate and `value: null` when tapping on the list tile produces:

```
flutter: 2020-08-15 12:14:41.735337 SHOUT main - Unhandled Flutter framework (gesture) error.
### Failed assertion: boolean expression must not be null
#0      CheckboxListTile.build.<anonymous closure> (package:flutter/src/material/checkbox_list_tile.dart:419:54)
#1      _InkResponseState._handleTap (package:flutter/src/material/ink_well.dart:989:19)
#2      _InkResponseState.build.<anonymous closure> (package:flutter/src/material/ink_well.dart:1098:38)
```

tapping on the Checkbox within the ListTile works as intended.

## Steps to Reproduce

create a `CheckboxListTile` with `tricheck: true`: Here an example: https://dartpad.dartlang.org/a50f547017bba61fc6c73f68aa100081

**Expected results:** <!-- what did you want to see? -->

true => null => false

**Actual results:** <!-- what did you see? -->

null error when `value` is null, otherwise:

true => false => tue => false

here the difference between tapping on the list tile vs tapping on the checkbox:

![checkboxilsttile-tristate](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/313066/90310478-e2b1a900-def1-11ea-9289-224b404c7f50.gif)

## Issue 
Hot reload and hot restart don't work at all. I need to stop the app and rebuild the whole thing again to see the changes.

## Steps to Reproduce

+ Open a screen that is present in any of the modules.
+ do changes in the build method of the screen.
+ do hot reload and also hot restart.

**Expected results:** The change should get reflected once the screen restarts.

**Actual results:** No change in the screen. It's as if the code is not actually synced to the device itself. 
I don't see any error in the console. In fact everything seems to look normal except that it doesn't work.

Recent versions of Xcode now throw warnings when projects default to iOS 8. We should:

  * Make the default template iOS 9.
  * Provide documentation as to how to target iOS 8 for those still wanting to do so.
  * Provide documentation as to how to migrate old projects.

cc @jmagman @xster @csells

## Steps to Reproduce

Run attached project.  If scaling is working, you should see the 3.x image, but the 1.x is always displayed.  I tested on 
* Nexus 6 API 30
* iPhone Pro Max Simulator
* iPhone Pro Simulator

** File Changed
In the sample project, I modified 
* main.dart to display the asset image
* pubspec.yaml to add asset references
* image files
** assets/image.jpg
** assets/2.0x/image.jpg
** assets/3.0x/image.jpg

**Expected results:**
I overlaid the scale on top of the image.  You should see the 3.x image but you see the 1.x image

From recent surveys, we have good evidence that Flutter developers are struggling with topics that are well explained on [flutter.dev/docs](https://flutter.dev/docs). In other words, we have the content that could help, but Flutter developers aren't finding it.

We currently have 280 pages on flutter.dev/docs. Nobody reads them top to bottom. Developers just don't know about all the nuggets of information that's in there, and they don't necessarily know or remember to search for it. (Googlers: http://go/thickening-tail.)

Primary research also suggests that "the % of users who visited tutorial/codelab and then API docs (or vice versa) was almost negligible. They started clicking on the links on the page and stayed in the API doc loop or website loop." (@jayoung-lee) And we have good indication from secondary research that cross linking helps users find what they need. (@cobblest)

## Use case

For example, if a new Flutter developer finds her way to the [`Simulation`](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/physics/Simulation-class.html) class on api.flutter.dev, she should be presented with a "See also" link that leads to the [Animate a widget using a physics simulation](https://flutter.dev/docs/cookbook/animation/physics-simulation) cookbook recipe on flutter.dev/docs.

This is already happening in some cases. See, for example, the last line in the [`TextField`](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/TextField-class.html) dartdoc.


## Proposal

I'm proposing to take the top 20-100 most-visited api.flutter.dev classes, and see if I can add meaningful links from them to flutter.dev/docs pages, through dartdocs.

I'm proposing to do this work myself, in a single PR. I just want to see if this is in line with what everyone's expecting from API docs.

## Use case

For instance, when I create a RaisedButton, where are all the default styling coming from the theme?

Now for a RaisedButton, it's possible to change any styling from the widget properties and also it's sometimes possible to intuitively figure it out, but widgets like datePicker, timePicker and Scrollbar don't have styling properties and don't tell you where from the theme they get their color from. 

The process of finding this information can be very cumbersome and time consuming. I've sometimes resolved this by searching google for the info and when that's not possible, digging into the underlying code of the widget.

## Proposal

In the docs, have a section where it mentions all styling and theme info for every widget.

I understand that for some widgets it could need "if then" clauses to know exactly where the default style comes from, but that is the exact point. Developers need to know this info and there's no good way to know as far as I know.

Currently, if `RenderIntrinsicWidth` is given tight constraints, it won't even ask its child for its intrinsic width - it'll just give the child the same constraints:

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/77efc00af09da019a2aec3e459c3d10049c562eb/packages/flutter/lib/src/rendering/proxy_box.dart#L641-L646

This seems wrong, and in contradiction to the documentation on the class:

> Sizes its child's width to the child's maximum intrinsic width ... This class is useful, for example, when unlimited width is available and you would like a child that would otherwise attempt to expand infinitely to instead size itself to a more reasonable width.

It seems like, much like `RenderFlex`, `RenderIntrinsicWidth` could honor its constraints while allowing its child to be smaller than the parent (`RenderIntrinsicWidth`).

For example, consider the following Render Tree:

```
RenderView
│ configuration: Size(800, 600) at 1.0x (in logical pixels)
│ size: Size(800, 600)
└ RenderIntrinsicWidth
  │ constraints: BoxConstraints(w=800, h=600)
  │ size: Size(800, 600)
  └ RenderConstrainedBox
    │ constraints: BoxConstraints(w=800, h=600)
    │ additionalConstraints: BoxConstraints(w=200, h=200)
    │ size: Size(800, 600)
```

In this case, the `RenderIntrinsicWidth` needs to be 800x600 because it received tight constraints by its parent `RenderView`.  However, it should relax those constraints that it passes to the child when it asks for the child's max intrinsic width to be:

```
childConstraints: BoxConstraints(0.0<=w<=800.0, h=600.0)
```

This would yield the following tree, which would be truer to the documented behavior of the render object:

```
RenderView
│ configuration: Size(800, 600) at 1.0x (in logical pixels)
│ size: Size(800, 600)
└ RenderIntrinsicWidth
  │ constraints: BoxConstraints(w=800, h=600)
  │ size: Size(800, 600)
  └ RenderConstrainedBox
    │ constraints: BoxConstraints(w=200, h=600) // because they're tightened to the child's intrinsic width
    │ additionalConstraints: BoxConstraints(w=200, h=200)
    │ size: Size(200, 600)
```

### Additional information

All of the above also applies to `RenderIntrinsicHeight`

Handling purchase updates is mentioned twice in the readme and I found this misleading, First in the "Initializing the plugin" section then in "Listening to purchase updates". Also, With so much information on how to make and handle purchases on each store, it can be confusing. Can we provide a standard and proven approach to have have in app purchases work flawlessly without diving into each store's documentation and trying to work out where each bit of code should be? eg. at app init, on the app's didChangeAppLifecycleState, etc... how should we acknoweldge pending purchases from past sessions or bought outside the App?

If there is a billing screen used as a paywall, what logic should be handled outside this screen and upon app init?

This isn't a problem (bug) with functionality, but a suggestion about accessibility instead. This library could be more accessible by being more clear about best practices for most common use cases.

The `checkProjects` parameter is confusing. By looking at the name, it is hard to figure out what it does.
We should add some documentation to explain what this parameter does. If there is a better name we can give to this parameter, we should also do that.

In the pubspec file, the following comment is automatically generated:

```
# The following defines the version and build number for your application.
# A version number is three numbers separated by dots, like 1.2.43
# followed by an optional build number separated by a +.
# Both the version and the builder number may be overridden in flutter
# build by specifying --build-name and --build-number, respectively.
# In Android, build-name is used as versionName while build-number used as versionCode.
# Read more about Android versioning at https://developer.android.com/studio/publish/versioning
# In iOS, build-name is used as CFBundleShortVersionString while build-number used as CFBundleVersion.
# Read more about iOS versioning at
# https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/General/Reference/InfoPlistKeyReference/Articles/CoreFoundationKeys.html
version: 1.0.0+1
```

Some terminology in the explanation is difficult to track.

Twice near the beginning of the comment, the terms "version" and "build number" are mentioned twice.

Later it is stated that "In Android, build-name is used as versionName while build-number used as versionCode". 

This then begs the question as to whether the Flutter pubspec "version" has any relation to how the Android version is determined.

To answer that question, one must take "build-name" and realize that it corresponds to the aforementioned "--build-name" flag, and then the reader needs to further recognize that the "--build-name" flag corresponds to the aforementioned term "version". Then you need to repeat this logical chaining to go from "versionCode" to "build-number" to "--build-number" to "build number".

Considering the criticality of correctly marking the version information for a packaged app, it might be a good idea to find a more concise and unambiguous explanation for the "version" property in the pubspec.

One idea would be to include a shorter explanation, but then show a literal Android example and a literal iOS example within the comment for the purpose of illustrating the "version" property applied in practice. That might suffice for a complete understanding.

I am working on an in-house plugin. It implements both ActivityAware and PluginRegistry.NewIntentListener. When the activity attaches, ActivityAware is automatically added as a listener (io.flutter.embedding.engine.FlutterEnginePluginRegistry:add()). However PluginRegistry.NewIntentListener does not trigger the same automatic listening and there is no documentation to suggest it is necessary to explicitly add it as a listener.

My assumption is the PluginRegistry listeners are interfaces for the plugin and should be registered, but I can see the intention of it being a separate/anonymous class so possibly the documentation needs clarification on how to use these listeners. I also relied on a plugin using the old registration system as a guide since there was no documentation on how to use.

 - When a modal is closed, the focus normally return to the button that opens it, whatever I do, the accessibility focus return to the first element of the screen;
 - When an option is selected in a dropdown, the focus should return on the dropdown field itself, but again, the focus return to the first element of the screen;

Instead it should be showing mocking out the platform provider, as is done [here](https://github.com/flutter/plugins/blob/master/packages/path_provider/path_provider/test/path_provider_test.dart), since that's the recommended way of mocking out plugins that are using the new platform interface structure.

The same Widget instance can be added multiple times (see https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Widget-class.html) so a Flutter app's widget hierarchy is actually a directed acyclic graph (DAG) instead of a tree. That is: the same Widget node could have multiple incoming edges as well as outgoing edges where an edge is a parent-child relationship. (The acyclic part comes from the fact that a widget is final and immutable so there's a topological order defined by the order of widget constructions, and therefore edges can't form a loop.)

However, it seems that we extensively use the term "Widget tree" in our docs, articles, slides, and tool descriptions (me included). See https://flutter.dev/docs/testing/code-debugging#widget-tree for an example.

After checking the source code, I find that "Widget tree dump" is actually calling [debugDumpApp][] which dumps the Element tree. (The Elements do form a tree as the same Widget at different locations will instantiate different Elements. See https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Element-class.html.)

This also happens in `flutter run` tool where `?` prints out `w Dump widget hierarchy to the console`. The `w` actually calls [debugDumpApp][] to print out the element tree instead of the widget DAG.

I wonder if we should clarify this so people get less confused, and are aware that they can reuse the same Widget instance multiple times in the hierarchy (which might be good for performance). Or is the Element so close to the Widget that it's Ok to just use the Widget tree to reference the Element tree?

[debugDumpApp]: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/28138ec5e3271ae35295a46bf2eeaf554eeb2535/packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/binding.dart#L977

## Use case

`.removeAt(index)` and `.removeLast()` don't do what their name suggests... they both return the element you are trying to remove from the list. We could say they are just "get" methods. I am curious why those methods are called that way.

In order to remove the first element you need to do 
```
yourList.removeRange(0, 1);
```

or in a value-typed list (like a String list) you also can do 
```
yourList.remove(yourList.removeAt(0));
```

That's quite confusing... 

The same if you need to remove the last item
```
yourList.removeRange(yourList.length - 1, yourList.length);
```

or
```
yourList.remove(yourList.removeLast())
```

## Proposal

I am sure there is an explanation to this, and I have being using those methods since always, but now I am curious why and if there is a chance to change the names (or implementation) of those methods...

At the moment neither the [style guide](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Style-guide-for-Flutter-repo) nor the [contributor guide](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) specify for which platforms a feature in a pull request has to be available to be merged. 

In https://github.com/flutter/plugins/pull/1400 it's argued that Android, iOS and web are all three required. If that's the official policy that should be stated in one of the linked documents so that developers don't get pull request denied for reasons of unstated policy.

If this isn't policy then the policy should be also explicitely say that pull requests that only implement some platforms like Android+iOS are welcome to encourage developers to contribute those. 

Given that the amount of features in Flutters plugins are at the moment it's weakest point I would prefer a policy that's welcoming of pull requests that implement a feature in Android + iOS and that doesn't require web, but in any case there should be an official policy.

The `TabBar` docs mention:

```dart
  /// If [indicator] is not null, then [indicatorWeight], [indicatorPadding], and
  /// [indicatorColor] are ignored.
```

But it fails to remind the user that an `indicator` can be provided into the App's theme using `TabBarTheme`, in that case the internal reference `_indicator` won't be null and `indicatorColor` and the others will be ignored. This brings confusion as the `TabBar` `indicator` property was indeed `null`, but the `TabBar` got an `indicator` from the App's `Theme`.

I suggest that the docs get updated to include this case or the behavior of the `TabBar` be updated to match its docs.

## Use case
We want the user to have animation when he goes forward or backward in the navigation stack by using the UI or the physical buttons in the device.
But when we use the method Navigator.popUntil programmatically, animation should not show, or a different animation should show.

## Proposal
The method Navigator.popUntil should have an optional boolean parameter showAnimation where false can be passed. By this, popUntil would take the user to the first screen in the stack without showing any animations.

Java Heap
Native Heap
Code
Stack
Graphics
Private Other
System

We should have explanation of each of these metrics in **Flutter context**.

In Flutter 1.17.0, a [breaking change](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/48541) was made to `ParentDataWdiget`. A new method `debugTypicalAncestorWidgetClass` requires users to override and return `Type` of its ancestor widget.

However, the ancestor could be a generic type, and Dart [does not support](https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk/issues/11923) generic type literals.

Since it is a relatively uncommon pattern in Flutter (AFAIK), and the [solution](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52891537/how-to-get-generic-type) is tricky to get around this Dart limitation, it could be confusing whether the user should return with or without generic type arguments. So mentioning this in documentation for relevant APIs can be helpful.

In several classes, including at least the [Column class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Column-class.html), [Expanded class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Expanded-class.html), and the [Flexible class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Flexible-class.html), the wrong form of "its" is used.

Possible fix:

`sed -i {file} -e "s/it's flex value/its flex value/g" -e "s/it's middle child/its middle child/g"`

Current [DataTable docs](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/DataTable-class.html) may confuse people about sorting: [1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51434778/flutter-using-datatable-sorting-built-in-function), [2](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61563024/sorting-column-values-in-flutter-datatable).

It might be cleaner to explicitly point that rows aren't sorted automatically when passing `sortColumnIndex`/`sortAscending` and should be sorted manually if needed, e.g. in StatefulWidget

https://github.com/bsutton/flutter_sound

The api needs to handle events when the application changes its state (AppLifecycleState.pause/resume). (we need to stop/resume audio when the app is paused/resumed).

I can see how to do this in a widget using WidgetsBindingObserver but the api needs this same info without having to rely on a widget.

The SchedulerBinding class has a method handleAppLifecycleStateChanged which seems to provide the required info but its unclear how to implement this outside of a widget.

I'm unable to find any documentation on this issue.
I've tried stack overflow without any response: 

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61449993/flutter-how-to-track-app-lifecycle-without-a-widget

A pointer at some doco or an update of the existing doco would be helpful.

Thanks.

## Background

[The characters package](https://pub.dev/packages/characters) was recently introduced to address Dart String's limitations of manipulating extended grapheme clusters (https://github.com/dart-lang/language/issues/34). However, our user study shows that it is often difficult for developers to identify use cases where the characters package should be used instead of the Dart String API. 

## Proposal
As part of a larger plan to help developers make better API choices for text manipulation tasks, it would be helpful to suggest the characters package in the documentation of APIs that expect the developer to process text that might include extended grapheme clusters. Providing sample code that have `characters` included would be especially useful since no everyone reads the doc carefully.

Building on the [Character Library's Impact Beyonds Text Related Widgets.](https://docs.google.com/document/d/18SxWeHpds4modnvo997vIOiq01EspeFgsNvPa5ey88w/edit#) doc, I suggest the following changes:

### TextField-related
- [ ] Use `characters` in the [reading values sample code](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/TextField-class.html#reading-values) for the `TextField` class.
- [ ] Use `characters` in [the sample code](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/TextField/onChanged.html) for the `onChange` property of the `TextField` class.
- [ ] Add sample code to the [API doc of TextInputFormatter](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/services/TextInputFormatter-class.html) and use `characters` in the sample. 

### showSearch

- [ ] Recommend developers use `characters` in the documentation of [showSearch](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/showSearch.html) or [SearchDelegate](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/SearchDelegate-class.html) and provide a sample.

### CircleAvatar
- [ ] In the [Flutter Gallery demo of CircleAvatar](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/dev/integration_tests/flutter_gallery/lib/demo/material/tabs_demo.dart), use `characters` to access the first character in a string.

###  Navigator
- [ ] Provide some guidance on parsing route names that might include extended grapheme clusters. More context in [this doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/18SxWeHpds4modnvo997vIOiq01EspeFgsNvPa5ey88w/edit#heading=h.9w7ovhhbaioc).

Feel free to create sub-issues to make this more manageable. This issue is currently blocked by https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/53381 and https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/55593.

Cc: @chunhtai

I have built a video calling app in Flutter using the Agora SDK. This is only available for iOS/Android and so for the web build I had to build a wrapper around the existing Agora web SDK. Due to the way Flutter renders web elements inside a shadow DOM, you cannot access elements by document.getElementById(), which is what the Agora SDK uses to inject their video player. To get around this I am rendering an IFrame that has the div and Agora SDK script bundled together. It is all working nicely but when any event is triggered inside the browser window, such as the mouse entering a button or clicking anything, the IFrame refreshes and rebuilds the video view which takes 1-2 seconds to initialize. Is there anyway I can unlink the IFrame from the browser events? I tried marking the HtmlElementView as const and putting it inside a StatefulWidget that only registers the platform view once. The widget isn't actually running the build() method again but the IFrame still refreshes. Flutter Code: ``` ui.platformViewRegistry.registerViewFactory( 'video-container', (int viewId) => IFrameElement() ..id = 'my-iframe' ..width = '100%' ..height = '100%' ..src = 'assets/web_elements/agora_container.html' ..allow = "camera; microphone" ..style.border = 'none'); @override Widget build(BuildContext context) { print("*****\n\n\nBuilding the web host container\n\n\n*****"); // this is only printing once return const HtmlElementView( viewType: 'video-container', ); } ``` Agora Code: ```

Currently I am using **Flutter** to build my application.

**Background**
I have followed some guide on building different environments entry files:
https://iirokrankka.com/2018/03/02/separating-build-environments/
which create main_dev.dart and main_prod.dart.

Also I have learnt to build flavor for both iOS and Android: https://medium.com/@salvatoregiordanoo/flavoring-flutter-392aaa875f36
which now I can use --flavor <FLAVOR> in the command to build different flavor application.

Now I have encountered a problem when I try to combine two skills.

**Target Result**
Below is what I would like to achieve:

development flavor -> main_dev.dart entry file
production flavor -> main_prod.dart entry file

Problem Encounter
in iOS side, I can target the entry file in .xcconfig file like following:

```
// ios/Flutter/development.xcconfig

#include "Generated.xcconfig"

FLUTTER_TARGET=lib/main_dev.dart
```

I know I can add -t lib/main_dev.dart after flutter run command.
However I would like to ask if there is any solution to set
the flutter target file in Android side inside flavor config?

Appreciate for any help.

Hello!  I was trying to add Flutter to my existing Android workspace and ran into two problems.  One of which sure seems like a bug.

I was following the guide here: ↪https://flutter.dev/docs/development/add-to-app/android/project-setup

I couldn't get the "Using Android Studio" steps to work after several clean attempts.  I tried the "Manual integration" and "Option B - Depend on the module’s source code" steps instead.

1. Follow the instructions
2. Carefully ensure that one follows the "Tip"
`Tip: By default, the host app provides the :app Gradle project. To change the name of this project, set flutter.hostAppProjectName in the Flutter module’s gradle.properties file. Finally, include this project in the host app’s settings.gradle file mentioned below.`
3. Android Studio cannot sync with Gradle due to this error message in "Logs" below.

## WORK-AROUND
Edit `flutter/packages/flutter_tools/gradle/flutter.gradle` to replace references to `:app` with the existing app modules identifier.  Everything works fine!
- My expectation is I shouldn't have to edit 600+ line scripts built in to the Flutter SDK to complete the bootstrap guide 🍭

The `TextTheme.button` documentation says:

```
  /// Used for text on [RaisedButton] and [FlatButton].
  final TextStyle button;
```

But RaisedButton actually uses: 
```
textStyle: theme.textTheme.button.copyWith(color: buttonTheme.getTextColor(this)),
```

So the color of the text on a raised button does not actually come from TextTheme.button but from ButtonTheme.getTextColor, which is misleading.

The documentation should be updated to point out that everything but the color of the text style is used or the text style should just be used as assumed.

## Related

* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56517959/flutter-change-all-raised-button-text-color-in-theme

`Visibility` `maintainSize` docs have a big paragraph explaining the costs of `maintainSize` with `maintainAnimation` and `maintainState`. The whole language looks like a good tutorial to know when do we choose to apply each one of those options. But that's not the case as we don't really have any options here, `maintainSize = true` forces us to use `maintainAnimation = true` and `maintainState = true`.

To be clearer. the docs only say that `To set this, [maintainAnimation] must also be set.`, so if `maintainSize` is set to `true`, then `maintainAnimation` should also be `true`. But on `maintainAnimation` docs we see that `To set this, [maintainState] must also be set.`, so implicitly **if `maintainSize` is set to `true`, then both `maintainAnimation` and `maintainState` should also be `true`.**

`maintainSize` docs should include that `maintainState` should also be true, and the big paragraph explaining it's costs should make it clearer that it's just an explanation on the costs and not something we can actually choose when to use each option separately.

The `Tooltip` docs say:

>Wrap the button in a Tooltip widget to show a label when the widget long pressed (or when the user takes some other appropriate action).

The `(or when the user takes some other appropriate action)` implies we could choose other actions to show the `Tooltip`, or that at least they are already built-in, but the docs don't mention any other ways to show the `Tooltip` neither how to reconfigure it's default behavior, like changing "long-press" to "on tap".

The only hint I could get to the explanation of this sentence is in the `waitDuration` description where it says the `Tooltip` will also be shown on a pointer hover.

So are the docs incomplete or the `Tooltip` should have additional functionality?

Not quite sure where to post this -- I've seen several otherwise greatly designed Flutter apps where a given clickable widget, like when swipe-scrolled sideways, can't be clicked as it finalizes its animation. For instance, this happens with the Reflectly story day widgets. As the animation is usally easing out (i.e. its near-final animation state is almost still), this can lead to certain micro-issues like the user having to click twice to open something without properly understanding why; one can also not navigate the app as intuitively fast as one wants to, but always has to wait for the animation to settle in.

So I guess my question is, is this a native issue with Flutter, or perhaps something not native but easy to run into given common Flutter coding patterns? And if so, could it be optimized? Or is this simply a result of the app using a non-suggested implementation pattern? Thanks!

The `Navigator` docs say `A widget that manages a set of child widgets with a stack discipline.`, so this induces us to believe the `Navigator` will add some sort of hierarchy to the pushed Routes, but anyone that tried to get an `InheritedWidget` from inside a new Route will get an error (unless the `InheritedWidget` is on top of the `MaterialApp`).

As [this article](https://medium.com/@mehmetf_71205/inheriting-widgets-b7ac56dbbeb1) shows, one could expect our app to look like this:

```
> School App [App Context]
  > Student [Student Context]
    > Grades
    > Bio
  > Teacher [Teacher Context]
    > Courses
    > Bio
```

But Navigator will actually make it look like this:

```
> School App [App Context]
  > Student [Student Context]
  > Student Grades
  > Student Bio
  > Teacher [Teacher Context]
  > Teacher Courses
  > Teacher Bio
```

This behavior is misleading and induces errors (I spent 2 hours trying to understand why my `Provider` wasn't working once I navigated further), so it should be added to the docs.

@blasten called this out last year. This was also extensively worked on by our China customers https://www.infoq.cn/article/iYGyKQowuiUN_Gi2hHDo. 

For lightweight "detached" development, it makes sense for Flutter module developers to be able to bootstrap their module and launch/test their module both in a standalone fashion and also in normal 'production' mode integrated into their bigger host app. 

Document the best practices for this approach. 

Relates to https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/32989 and http://flutter.dev/go/everything-builds-from-a-module as well. 

I'm of the opinion that the standalone run shell should be another (albeit simpler) add-to-app host app that wraps the same Flutter module and that supplies it with upstream dependencies, data etc.

Describe best practice for managing and sharing upstream dependencies like Crashalytics that's being used both by the platform and Flutter. 

cc @jmagman @RedBrogdon

Hi.
I've used official plugin for payments. I would like to implement auto-renewal subscriptions. In android implementation it is very easy. Problem is in iOS. serverVerificationData isn't a payment token (as in android payment). I must valid it before sending to server and I must decode it. Decoding by base64 return bytes. It is probably ASN1. I am trying to get to payment token from it by plugin asn1lib. My attemps are failed. 
How can I get payment token from iOS?

There is a prop that can configure the text capitalization in Flutter: 

https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/TextField/textCapitalization.html

but it only works for the platform keyboard. Is it planned to have an implementation that will work on non-platform keyboards?

Hello, I'm trying to use TradingView Charting library with Flutter, as a reference, I'm using this Android implementation https://github.com/tradingview/charting-library-examples/blob/master/android/app/src/main/java/com/tradingview/android/MainActivity.kt

This is how I load it:

```
  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) => WebView(
    initialUrl: "about:blank",
    javascriptMode: JavascriptMode.unrestricted,
    onWebViewCreated: (controller) async {
      _controller = controller;

      var headers = <String, String>{
        'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*',
        'Access-Control-Allow-Methods': 'POST, GET, OPTIONS',
        'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials': 'true'
      };

      await _controller.loadUrl("file:///android_asset/flutter_assets/assets/charting_library/index.html", headers: headers);
    }
  );
```

It does work until the library creates an iframe (loading another file from the assets) and tries to change it via javascript, I will get a lot of error messages like this one:

`I/chromium(13460): [INFO:CONSOLE(1)] "Uncaught (in promise) SecurityError: Blocked a frame with origin "null" from accessing a frame with origin "null". Protocols, domains, and ports must match.", source: file:///android_asset/flutter_assets/assets/charting_library/charting_library/charting_library.min.js (1)`

It seems that the issue is that the origin is "null", is there some way to change it? I tried with the headers from the above code without success.

I'm not sure how to fix this and why it happens in flutter but not with the android example.

PS: I'm using latest flutter webview version ^0.9.6+2

After upgrade in_app_purchase package 0.2.0 to 0.3.1, all Non consumable products are refunded after three days.
So I search why purchases are refunded.
And finally I got solution.

In Document of in_app_purchase, We should call completePurchase only iOS after purchased non consumable product.
But 0.3.1+1 completePurchase said, 

/// Warning! Failure to call this method and get a successful response within 3 days of the purchase will result a refund on Android.
  /// The [consumePurchase] acts as an implicit [completePurchase] on Android.

If you don't call completePurchase on android purchase, All of that are refunded after three day....

Flutter team have to write this warning on README!!!

When using `Switch.adaptive()` constructor, users can be led to believe by the documentation of the `activeColor` property that the behavior also applies to iOS, which it doesn't (see @TahaTesser 's responses below).

(original text):

```

Modifying `toggleableActiveColor` for the app does not affect the color on iOS when using `Switch.adaptive`. Setting `activeColor` for the individual widget works as expected.

(transferred from /flutter/website) Consider the situation where you want to search `setState` on api.flutter.dev Logically, it should bring `State.setState` as the first result, since this is the only class that implements the method. The others just inherit from it. The reality is different: The search result is polluted by all the stateful widgets in the framework. In the end, we don't even see `State.setState` because there are too many results.

For those familiar with [API Key Best Practices](https://developers.google.com/maps/api-key-best-practices), the instructions for [Android](https://pub.dev/packages/google_maps_flutter#android) and [iOS](https://pub.dev/packages/google_maps_flutter#ios) make some nervous because it basically instructs them to store an API KEY in the source tree when there is an explicit rule against this practice: [Do not store API keys or signing secrets in files inside your application's source tree](https://developers.google.com/maps/api-key-best-practices#no_store_apikey).

Can the **documentation** be revised to explain why this is OK?

We should document some of our design decisions about how widgets build:

* The framework guarantees that ancestors build before descendants.
* The framework does not guarantee anything about the order other than this.
* Some widgets might in rare cases build twice, this is considered an aberration to be avoided (layout builder that ends up dirty both at the widget layer and the layout layer is the example).
* One pass build.

Maybe point to "Inside Flutter" (https://flutter.dev/docs/resources/inside-flutter).

https://b.corp.google.com/issues/149979662.

cc @chinmaygarde

Hello,

  I had one native plugin working without problems.
  I upgraded Flutter and Android (kotlin) and notice I had some serious error (crash the app)

  I could solve the problem, but with a "not cool solution". I search around and see some people in stack overflow with same problem as well in the end of January.

  The problem is with this method: onAttachedToActivity()
  When this method is called, by the Wiki (https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Experimental:-Create-Flutter-Plugin) it says:
   
> "If you are creating channels in your onAttachToEngine(), there is no need to cleanup those creations in onDetachFromEngine() and creating them again the second time onAttachToEngine() is called is fine."

  So, first, the problem explanation I could investigate:

The code:
```kotlin
  override fun onAttachedToActivity(binding: ActivityPluginBinding) {
    Log.v("PLUGIN", "[ onAttachedToActivity ]")
    Log.v("PLUGIN", "  Binding: $binding")
  }
```

The output:
```
I/flutter: Observatory listening on http://127.0.0.1:36799/C30Q3sI3Mho=/
D/FlutterActivityAndFragmentDelegate: Attaching FlutterEngine to the Activity that owns this Fragment.
V/PLUGIN: [ onAttachedToActivity ]
V/PLUGIN:   Binding: io.flutter.embedding.engine.FlutterEnginePluginRegistry$FlutterEngineActivityPluginBinding@2593b8c
V/PLUGIN: [ onAttachedToActivity ]
V/PLUGIN:   Binding: io.flutter.embedding.engine.FlutterEnginePluginRegistry$FlutterEngineActivityPluginBinding@2593b8c
D/FlutterView: Attaching to a FlutterEngine: io.flutter.embedding.engine.FlutterEngine@d689fbc
```

  As you can see, the app calls 2 times the onAttachedToActivity.
  I have one class that is created there ```MethodCallHandlerImpl```. Then I will end up with 2 instances of it.
  When I use the ```binding.addRequestPermissionsResultListener(this)``` in this class to I got notification when the user accepts/denies the calendar read access, I end up with 2 calls for ```override fun onRequestPermissionsResult( ... )```, but only one of the instances receive the Dart/Platform code from ```override fun onMethodCall( ... )```

I made a little debug to check all the information above.
If I get the ```MethodChannel.Result``` as private variable member of the class when the ```onMethodCall``` is called, I will have two calls for ```onRequestPermissionsResult```. One of this calls is being from ```onMethodCall```, so the ```MethodChannel.Result``` is initialized. The other call is from the instance that the method ```onMethodCall``` was **not** called ! Then the ``MethodChannel.Result``` does not exists, was not initialized and the app will crash.


**The solutions**

Solution 1:
I solved this error with an inline callback in ```onMethodCall``` that will use the ```MethodChannel.Result``` from the method parameters. But I still will have 2 ```override fun onRequestPermissionsResult( ... )``` calls.

Solution 2:
Another solution is, when ```onAttachedToActivity``` be called, I can remove the binding listener to just use one ```MethodCallHandlerImpl``` and destroy the old, but I don't know the complications of this.


**Comments**
I think the right lifecycle would be attach and detach, but maybe it's attaching twice because some new internal Flutter lifecycle with Android Views/Activity

I can provide an empty plugin example with the error and the solution if needed, but only can send it in Monday (10 Feb).


Thanks in advance!

> The critical thing I was looking for in this project [the android_alarm_manager plugin] was how to initialise the background isolate.

> There are various comments in `FlutterBackgroundExecutor` which touch on things that I would love to see fully explained in the guide and API documentation:
> 
> ```java
>       // We need to create an instance of `FlutterEngine` before looking up the
>       // callback. If we don't, the callback cache won't be initialized and the
>       // lookup will fail.
>       FlutterCallbackInformation flutterCallback =
>           FlutterCallbackInformation.lookupCallbackInformation(callbackHandle);
> ```
> 
> This isn't mentioned in the migration guide and is also not mentioned in the javadoc for `FlutterCallbackInformation`.
> 
> Also:
> 
> ```java
>       // The pluginRegistrantCallback should only be set in the V1 embedding as
>       // plugin registration is done via reflection in the V2 embedding.
>       if (pluginRegistrantCallback != null) {
>         pluginRegistrantCallback.registerWith(new ShimPluginRegistry(backgroundFlutterEngine));

> 
> The migration guide does not explain how this reflection approach works.
> 
> Assuming that for each `FlutterEngine` instance, the `GeneratedPluginRegistrant` is automatically called and a new instance of the plugin class is created and attached to the engine resulting in a 1-to-1 mapping between engines and plugins, how does a plugin instance detect whether it is running in a flutter engine that is associated with the activity/ui vs the headless engine? I used to be able to test whether `registrar.activity()` returned null, but now I assume I have to override `onAttachedToEngine` and figure this out from the `FlutterPluginBinding` parameter.

> ```java

>   }
> ```
> 
> And even if it were fine for me to call the deprecated `getFlutterEngime` method, I do not see any way from there to get the `RenderSurface` and test whether it's null.
> I can now see that `ServiceAware` might be the way to do it, but this API doesn't seem to work, and none of the official plugins demonstrate how to use it. I made my plugin implement both `ActivityAware` and `ServiceAware` but only the lifecycle methods of the former were actually called. I also passed in my `Service` instance as the constructor argument when creating the background `FlutterEngine` but this itself didn't cause the `ServiceAware` callbacks to be called.
> 
> In any event, I got my plugin working with v2 using a different approach.
> 
> As some constructive feedback, I do appreciate all the hard work the Flutter team is doing, BUT I also hope that this migration experience is not something I will ever have to go through again. ## Steps to Reproduce

There are two distinct but related breakages here: double registration and too early registration when automatic registration is relied on. I'm going to describe them both below.

### Double registration

#### Reproduction Steps

1. Run `flutter create -t app` with flutter stable (v.12.13)
2. Include any plugin using the v1 embedding that doesn't require an activity (for example, `firebase_messaging`)
3. `flutter run` on an Android device.

**Expected results:** Plugin should be registered and function normally.

**Actual results:** The plugin is registered twice (visible with a debugger), leading to plugin-specific bugs caused by multiple instances of the same plugin class responding to single MethodChannel calls. For example, see https://github.com/FirebaseExtended/flutterfire/issues/1669: a particular plugin method is always called twice.

### Early registration

#### Reproduction Steps

1. Run `flutter create -t app` with flutter stable (v1.12.13)
2. Remove the template `MainActivity` in favor of `FlutterActivity` [as recommended by our official migration docs](https://flutter.dev/docs/development/packages-and-plugins/plugin-api-migration).
3. Include any plugin using the v1 embedding that requires an activity (for example, `google_maps_flutter`).
4. `flutter run` on an Android device.

**Expected results:** Plugin should be registered and function normally.

**Actual results:** The plugin is registered before the activity is set on the shim registrar (visible with a debugger), leading to plugin-specific bugs caused by the null activity. For example, see flutter/flutter#47921: the plugin appears to never be registered and is completely unusable.

## Background

Automatic plugin registration was proposed [in this doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xNkBmcdVL1yEXqtZ65KzTwfr5UXDD05VVKYXIXGX7p8/edit#) and merged in flutter/engine#13455. The goal stated in the doc is to remove boilerplate code in user apps, but I think it may also have been to support background registration. (@bkonyi @matthew-carroll to confirm)

The v1 registration flow expected plugins to be registered once, and the registration call to contain any information the plugin may need (like an `Activity`). The v2 registration flow in contrast is done over a series of lifecycle callbacks and never propagates all the necessary information for a plugin at a single call. The v2 registration flow is supposed to still be compatible with v1-only plugins through a `ShimPluginRegistry`, which internally listens to all the v2 callbacks.

## Status

_Edited 1/27/2020_: This has been fixed in the framework as of flutter/flutter@4fbb85e0c207132e0ed9130d7410784c00f0d066, but still hasn't rolled to any channels or versions other than master. 

## Suggested fix

We disable the current automatic registration call in `FlutterEngine` when it's constructed via `FlutterActivity` and add an automatic registration call into the `configureFlutterEngine` of the `FlutterActivity` superclass. That way it will get called at the appropriate time in both the foreground and background case automatically and will still be under Flutter source code instead of user code. As a bonus the generated template doesn't call `super()` so this should automatically fix the problem in existing user apps without the need for a migration. The "ugly" part here is that from now on we're going to expect users to call `super()` when they override `configureFlutterEngine` if they're not registering plugins themselves, and it's been a no-op before. So people who have been deliberately overriding it will be impacted. I'm unaware of any such cases today.

_Edit: The purpose is to avoid having critical code in a user template, not just removing boilerplate. This is a stronger case to avoid reverting._ ~~**If** the automatic registration was only to remove boilerplate code, I suggest we revert that change and change all our official docs to recommend registering plugins in a subclass of `FlutterActivity`, like the template. Knowing the "right" place to correctly automatically register v1 plugins with the v2 embedding so that they have all their required state is difficult since the embedding can be completely decoupled from any kind of activity or service at all. The boilerplate is regrettable but preferable to bugs.~~

_Edit: This won't work for all background cases, figured out in an offline discussion._ ~~Assuming the automatic registration is necessary to support background cases better, @amirh suggested a plan where at a high level we can basically avoid this problem by still automatically registering eventually, but delaying the automatic registration until the plugin registry is either attached to an activity (for foreground cases) or a service (for background cases). Then we should change the tool's template and urge users to migrate away from the currently `MainActivity` registration call.~~ 

## Related Issues

- flutter/flutter#47921
- flutter/flutter#49346
- FirebaseExtended/flutterfire#1669

You have the mock interface documented thusly.

`SharedPrefernces.setMockInitialValues (Map<String, dynamic> values);`

Which is great, but the doc doesn't mention that your keys have to begin with the prefix 'flutter.' or they won't be found by the preferences.

Also the work Preferences in your sample code above is mis-spelt.

## Use case

This is what my test code has to look like in order to pass.

```
    SharedPreferences.setMockInitialValues({ "flutter.Prod_JWT_KEY": "key1", "flutter.Prod_USER_ID": "user1" });

    // test prefs mocking
    var prefs = await SharedPreferences.getInstance();
    expect(prefs.getString("Prod_JWT_KEY"), "key1");
```

Note the prefix 'flutter.' added to the keys map.

Its fine if this prefix is needed, but it should be documented. Better yet, modify `setMockInitialValues` to add the prefix to all the keys for you.

I'm trying to extend my Flutter Web application with some Rust code via WebAssembly. My project structure looks like this:
```
lib/
- main.dart
web/
  - wasm_demo/
     - src/
       - lib.rs
     - pkg/
       - wasm_demo.js
       - wasm_demo_bg.wasm
     - bootstrap.js
     - Cargo.toml
  - index.html
```
The Rust code just creates a `String` and returns it:
```rust
// web/wasm_demo/src/lib.rs

use wasm_bindgen::prelude::*;

#[wasm_bindgen]
pub fn get_string() -> String {
    String::from("This is a Rust String!")
}
```
When compiled with `wasm-pack build` the bytecode ends up in `web/wasm_demo/pkg/wasm_demo_bg.wasm`. `wasm_demo.js` is just a JavaScript module exporting the `get_string` function from `wasm_demo_bg.wasm`:
```js
import * as wasm from './wasm_demo_bg.wasm';

...

/**
* @returns {string}
*/
export function get_string() {
    ...
}
```
`bootstrap.js` imports that module and puts it into the `window` object:
```js
// bootstrap.js

import * as wasm_demo from "./pkg/wasm_demo";

window.wasm_demo = wasm_demo;
```
`index.html` loads that bootstrapper prior to launching the actual application:
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Rust/WASM/Flutter interop demo</title>
</head>

<body>
  <script src="wasm_demo/bootstrap.js" type="module"></script>

  <script src="main.dart.js" type="application/javascript"></script>
</body>

</html>
```
And finally, Flutter displays the Rust `String`:

```dart
import 'dart:js';

import 'package:flutter/material.dart';

void main() {
  runApp(MyApp());
}

class MyApp extends StatelessWidget {
  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return MaterialApp(
      title: 'Rust/WASM/Flutter interop demo',
      theme: ThemeData(
        primarySwatch: Colors.blue,
      ),
      home: MyHomePage(),
    );
  }
}

class MyHomePage extends StatelessWidget {
  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext buildContext) {
    var rustString = context["wasm_demo"].callMethod('get_string').toString();

    return Scaffold(
      appBar: AppBar(
        title: Text("Rust/WASM/Flutter interop demo"),
      ),
      body: Center(
        child: Text(rustString),
      ),
    );
  }
}
```

The problem I have is that `wasm_demo_bg.wasm` is apparently not included in the bundle:
```bash
:44809/wasm_demo/pkg/wasm_demo:1 Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 (Not Found)
```

Neither the Dart side [`Canvas.drawShadow`](https://github.com/flutter/engine/blob/eb05391962fb74e0152d6bb9827abdf341113de5/lib/ui/painting.dart#L4018) nor the engine side [`Canvas::drawShadow`](https://github.com/flutter/engine/blob/eb05391962fb74e0152d6bb9827abdf341113de5/lib/ui/painting/canvas.cc#L413), i.e. [`flutter::PhysicalShapeLayer::DrawShadow`](http://34.94.103.149/classflutter_1_1_physical_shape_layer.html#ac5d99b79c8a24ca58446d601af248db9) have *any* information on how **`elevation`** works exactly and I could also not find out what values do what exactly at different scales etc.  
The only thing I can say for sure is that the Flutter web implementation of the method behaves completely different than the native version.

## Needs better documentation

I think that better documentation for this function is needed in general, but more specifically I would like to know how `elevation` works exactly - from the native code I would have concluded that values from `0` to `600` make sense because [the light source is positioned at `z = 600`](http://34.94.103.149/namespaceflutter.html#af5a46f83182e00e27bf950417af3ea2b), however, that does not exactly line up with my experiments in native (I gave up on web behavior).  
Additionally, it would be useful to know where the light source is positioned - I would assume that it is positioned at `(0, 0, 600 * dpr)`, but I have no idea at this point.

I'm using vector_math-2.0.8/lib/src/vector_math_64/ray.dart for a ray-sphere intersection test, but I think the method supplied will only work correctly if the _direction component of a ray is a unit vector.

It also seems that at least one other method in the same file, at, assumes that _direction also has a magnitude of one.

There's nothing I've seen in the class or the documentation to suggest that the caller would know by convention that a unit vector is needed here, and actually to preserve the generality of the ray routines, I don't think we would require _direction to be a unit vector at the caller's end.

To fix this, we could normalise the direction vector in these two methods.  For intersectsWithSphere, I think line 57 could be changed to:

`final double s = l.dot(_direction.normalized());`

And for at, line 40 could be:

`Vector3 at(double t) => _direction.normalized().scale(t)..add(_origin);`

Does this sound like a good plan?

(Ps. just looking through the file, looks like generally the direction vector might need normalising before use eg. in copyAt.  Don't understand enough about the other intersection routines to have assessed those yet.)

This issue is primarily based on my Stack Overflow [post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59289344/how-exactly-should-i-host-a-dart-package-internally-in-an-internet-less-environm).

I am trying to host all the packages my flutter application depends in an svn repo and use it in a system without internet connection(unfortunately git is not possible yet) but has access to this svn repo.

**What I did so far:**

I do know I can use a path based dependency in my `pubspec.yaml` by using the `path` attribute. For e.g.

I can depend on a specific package named `xyz` by keeping it along with its dependecies in a folder say `packages` alongside the `lib` folder as shown below.

```
project
 |_ lib
 |_ packages
   |_ xyz
   |_ dep1_for_xyz
   |_ dep2_for_xyz
```
Then referring to it in `pubspec.yaml` as shown below and this works.

```
dependencies:
  flutter:
    sdk: flutter

  xyz:
    path: packages/xyz
```
But this seems very in efficient and dirty solution especially to keep all transitive dependencies along with the main dependencies. 

**Problems & question:**
I came across this environment variable `pub_hosted_url` in the following pages: [ref1][1] and [ref2][2].

I tried to use it as follows.

 1. Create an environment variable `pub_hosted_url` and point it to a directory in the remote svn repo.
    - for e.g., `https://username:password@repository_url/dart_packages`.
 2. Then add & commit a package inside this `dart_packages` folder.
    - for e.g. `built_value_generator-6.8.2` and all its relevant dependencies in a similar fashion.
 3. Then add the dependencies in the `pubspec.yaml` as usual.
    - for e.g `built_value_generator: ^6.7.1`
 4. Then run the `flutter pub get -v`.


***Problem1**:*
I am currently facing an Handshake error on client side. I understand this because of the certificate that svn server uses. Since its a self signed certificate,  flutter/pub/dart is unable to verify the validity of this certificate. 

following is the error I see.

```
[ +528 ms] IO  : Retry #1 for GET https://pub_hosted_url/api/packages/built_value_generator...
[   +3 ms] IO  : HTTP GET https://pub_hosted_url/api/packages/built_value_generator
[   +2 ms]     | Accept: application/vnd.pub.v2+json

[  +24 ms] IO  : HTTP error:

[   +1 ms]     |

[        ]     | package:pub/src/http.dart 68:39                    _PubHttpClient.send
[        ]     | package:http_retry/http_retry.dart 97:33           RetryClient.send

```

***Question1***
How do I let `flutter pub get` know that this is a trusted host or even add this certificate into its trusted list.

***A working Solution in my case*** 
This is based on this [comment](https://github.com/flutter/website/issues/2472#issuecomment-440462890).

1. First export the certificate using a broswer(Chrome in my case) and save it a local path e.g. desktop.
    - This usually would be with a `.cer` extension.
2. Then using `openssl` convert the `.cer` file into `.pem` file.
    - Using the command as shown [here](https://serverfault.com/questions/254627/how-do-i-convert-a-cer-certificate-to-pem).
3. Create an environment variable `DART_VM_OPTIONS` and set its value to  `--root-certs-file=<path_to_pem_file>`
4. Then running flutter packages get resolves the URL and initiates a correct connection.

Is this a correct solution.? A reference or guide could help. With some review help I will try to write a wiki page for this in the respective issue [here][4].

***Problem 2:***
This problem I see is from the above error message, where the packages are looked with the following url format `https://pub_hosted_url/api/packages/my_dependency`. This means the `flutter pub get` expects packages to be placed in a very specific format or specific location. I couldn't find any relevant documentation for this apart from this alpha level `pub_server` package [here][3].

We have a flavored Flutter application. Each flavor has a different bundle ID from a different Apple account.

The code signing is setup correctly on the Xcode Build Configurations, I can archive and deploy all my applications without a problem, but i can only launch one flavor on an iOS device from either Android Studio or VS Code because there is a "global" iOS signing certificate set for the project. I.e., if the "project certificate" is set to the certificate of flavor "A", when I try to run the flavor "B" on an iOS Device directly from both IDEs it will try to sign the flavor "B" with the certificate of flavor "A" and the Xcode build will fail.

The only way I have to launch the apps on a real iOS device is to perform a `flutter build ios debug --flavor <flavor> -t <main-file.dart> --no-codesign` and then run the desired flavor directly from Xcode, but of course when doing that I have no debugging on the dart code.
I use this flow of performing two builds when archiving and distributing the applications and it works as expected, the only problem I face is with the debug.

Since this issue is related only to code signing, the flavors also works as expected on the iOS Simulator, I can launch any flavor I want on debug on a simulator.

I could use `flutter config --clear-ios-signing-cert` to change the cert, but of course this isn't the ideal solution because I would still be stuck to one flavor at a time.

Am I doing any configuration wrong? Is there any way to configure flutter in order to get the code signing certificate for debug builds from the iOS configurations on Xcode instead of relying on the certificate set for the project?

**Steps to reproduce**

1) I run the **alpha** flavor using `flutter run -t lib/alpha-main.dart --flavor alpha`
2) It asked me to selected a development certificate from a list of available certificates and I selected the certificate for **alpha**.
3) The certificate for **alpha** is now set as default.
4) The app build and run on my device as expected.
5) I now tries to run **beta** flavor using `flutter run -t lib/beta-main.dart --flavor beta`
6) flutter run tries to sign **beta** app with the **alpha** signing certificate.
7) The build fails.

Today, setting `liveRegion` to true marks an iOS accessibility node with [`UIAccessibilityTraitUpdatesFrequently`](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiaccessibilitytraitupdatesfrequently?language=objc), which doesn't actually announce anything.

We _could_ make the experience a bit closer to Android by sending an explicit announcement when a live region actually updates (we already have the information we'd need to do that in the bridge).  It's not clear to me whether this would be a good idea or not though - unlike regular live region announcemnts (which in Flutter are always "polite"), it's not clear that announce would allow for interruptions from VoiceOver.

If we think this is the wrong way to go, we should probably provide better guidance than we do in the documentation beyond saying "this works in Android but not in iOS" - I would find it helpful to know what kind of approaches I should or should not consider taking (e.g., why or whether I should avoid doing `SemanticsService.announce` on iOS, or perhaps just why Flutter doesn't do that for me automatically on iOS).

/cc @goderbauer @jonahwilliams @darrenaustin @vick08 @caseyburkhardt @cbracken

This is when targetting Android API 29 and when including either "flutter_isolate" or "flutter_sqlcipher" in pubspec.yaml

The reason I've raised here instead of the individual plugins is because this issue spans multiple plugins and only occurred when switching to the beta channel (with no change to the plugin version). So my theory is that the cause is due to a recent underlying change within flutter. 

Or if not a direct flutter issue, there needs to be some guidance to plugin developers about changes they need to make, so they can make sure they know how to make their plugins compatible with the latest beta or dev builds? (otherwise they will fail when beta gets promoted to stable)

(on a separate note I still find the fact of needing to have a separate plugin such as "flutter_isolate" just to use plugins like "encrypt" from within an isolate less than ideal!)

I currently develop an alarm app and I want to play alarm sounds. 
There are various independent packages but they don't seem like they support all platforms and support the ability to play the sound in AudioManager.STREAM_ALARM loudness on Android.

While I looked at playing the audio I looked at video_player. Given that it's build on ExoPlayer and ExoPlayer can also play mp3's there's hope that video_player can play mp3s. Unfortunately, the documentation isn't clear about whether it can. If it can't it should be explicit about that.

Someone pointed out that the [documentation for `InputDecorator`'s constructor](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/InputDecoration/InputDecoration.html) says that `isDense` defaults to true, when it actually defaults to false (well, null, but that is later interpreted as false).

## Steps to Reproduce

1. import `dart:html`
2. run flutter test

Hi everybody. 
This issue is (probably) solved for me, but I thougt you should know (and maybe write it into some guideline somewhere):

When I tried compiling using gradle 5.4.1 (or 5.1.1, same story), compilation in debug or release mode gave me the following error: 
```
> Task :in_app_purchase:javaPreCompileDebug FAILED
[...]
<warning about breaking builds without AndroidX compatibility>
[...]
Gradle task assembleDebug failed with exit code 1

#0      throwToolExit (package:flutter_tools/src/base/common.dart:28:3)
[...]
```

Everything seems to be working fine with gradle 6.0.1 after setting:
```distributionUrl = https\://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-6.0.1-all.zip```
in the gradle-wrapper.properties file.

Not sure if you know about this - I didn't, and had quite a bit of work figuring it out.
Hope this helps somebody else. ;-)

On the material icons there are previews of each icon:

https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/material/Icons-class.html

However the same is not the case for the Cupertino icons:

https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/cupertino/CupertinoIcons-class.html

I don't know if there's a technical reason for this - it'd be nice to support if possible. In VS Code we use a regex to find these icon previews for Material and swap them out with images that will work there (so you have in-editor previews), but this also fails for Cupertino. If there were previous on the page, we could probably do the same thing there (raised at https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/issues/638#issuecomment-555022586).

## Use case

My app must manage focus and the on-screen keyboard.  I read the provided documentation:
* [FocusNode class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/FocusNode-class.html)
  * Contains a single example of how to create a widget that can focus/unfocus itself and change its behavior depending on its focus state.
* [Focus class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Focus-class.html)
  * Contains a partial example, which is an excerpt of the FocusNode example.
* [FocusScope class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/FocusScope-class.html)
  * No examples
* [FocusManager class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/FocusManager-class.html)
  * No examples.  Documentation explains briefly what it does, but makes no mention of how to use it for anything.
* [FocusScopeNode class](https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/FocusScopeNode-class.html)
  * No examples.

I found the provided documentation to be missing key information:
1. How to use Focus and FocusScope to control focus in an application with multiple widgets.
1. Examples of common use-cases:
   * How to focus a widget in response to a tap.
   * How to automatically focus a new widget.
   * How to unfocus a widget.
   * How to keep a widget focused.
   * How to keep a focused widget visible.
   * How to keep the keyboard on screen.
   * How to determine when the keyboard is visible and update the display accordingly.
   * How to move focus from one widget to the next in a form.
   * How to specify the order of widget focus movement.
   * How to provide expected software keyboard decorations to move from one widget to the next.
   * How to dismiss the software keyboard on non-Android platforms.

My app requires all of these use-cases.  So far, I have made-do with reading Flutter's source code (a huge time sink), stackoverflow answers, and snippets shared in Flutter issues.  My implementations are unsatisfactory in many ways.  Today I have just wasted 2 hours trying to solve the problem of keeping the keyboard on screen on iOS, still with no solution.  Focus management is an area where I have sunk a lot of time working around missing parts of Flutter.  It has been and continues to be a struggle, a large energy sink.  I want to be building features and solving problems for my users, not fighting against the UX framework.

I think better documentation would help me and other app developers to arrive at good solutions quickly.

## Proposal

Please allocate some time to writing some high-level documentation on managing keyboard focus in Flutter.

## Steps to Reproduce

Whenever i try to use the "Migrate to androidx" option on android studio, i keep getting the "No usages found in this project". I have tried to follow these solutions : 
- set compiled sdk to 28.
- enabled google play services.
- included `android.useAndroidX=true (and) android.enableJetifier=true`
- https://medium.com/@carlosAmillan/fixing-androidx-error-in-flutter-f35e18d5925
- https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/29249

I have been trying to find a solution for almost 3 hours. If there are any suggestions for a solution please point them out.
